Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status
Story: I was scrubbing the kitchen floor, sweat beading on my forehead, when my phone buzzed again. My wife’s voice echoed from the living room, “Can you help me with the guest towels?” Relatives were arriving in two hours, and every corner of the house had to be spotless. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. Then my phone buzzed a second time—a message from a customer: “Where’s my package? I need it urgently.” As a delivery person, I was expected to respond quickly and professionally, no matter what. My fingers hovered over the screen, torn between crafting a polite reply and rushing to help my wife. I could hear her frustration building, and I knew the customer was waiting, probably growing impatient. My mind raced, caught between the demands of being a supportive husband and a reliable delivery person. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing down, unsure which responsibility to answer first.
